turns.speaker: DINO VELVET
turns.text: Don't let Longdale's questionable choice of weapon give you any ideas. If his fey little gun puts enough little holes in you, you'll be just as dead... and so will Max.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: What can I do for you, Mr. Welles?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Call me Tom.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Alright, Tom.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: What I'd like, very simply, is access to your archive.  And, now I understand this isn't something you normally do for private citizens...

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: There are reasons for the way we do things here.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Absolutely.  Of course I'll abide by whatever decision you make, but I'd appreciate if you'll hear me out...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Few days ago, I was contacted by a couple living in Philadelphia, a doctor and his wife.  What happened was they picked up a young girl hitchhiking off 81, which heads into Philadelphia, started up a conversation with this girl, she looked homeless, seemed about eighteen maybe.  They convinced her to let them buy her a meal in the city.  Nice kid, mature, didn't have much to say, but they got a sense she's a runaway, so all through dinner the doctor's working on her, trying to convince her that at the very least she should pick up a telephone.  Not surprisingly, she ate her food, excused herself...  That's the last they saw her.  The reason they came to me for help, the reason I'm coming to you, is we had a friend of mine in the department work up a sketch...  They want to see if I can I.D. this girl, somehow pass along a message to let the parents know the kid's alive, doing alright.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Why not go to the N.C.I.C. or N.C.M.E.C.?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: This doctor and wife, they're nice people, but they don't want to get too involved.  They're not trying to have the parents come looking for the girl either. You and I both know sometimes, not often, but sometimes there's real reasons why a kid'll run. Molestation, whatever.  Besides that, the girl's probably eighteen, so she's legal.

turns.text: I'm not so sure about this.

Anyone with a computer and enough patience can find anything he wants.  It's heaven for those degenerate chicken-hawks. They're swapping pictures back and forth as fast as their modems can zap 'em.  But, there's still some weird shit under the counter where I work sometimes.  No one knows where it comes from.  That's local underground, where information spreads by word of mouth.  Those are zombies, hardcore junkies.  Their hands are permanently pruned.  They go out in the sun they don't burn, they blister.  Other than that, all I know about is the mail. But, if you're asking me who do you go to to get illegal shit... who knows? turns.text: Dino Velvet... yeah, he's like the John Luc Godard of S+M flicks, supposed to be a real weirdo.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: A weirdo making S+M films?  Who'd have thought it?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: His stuff comes out of New York. Bondage and fetish videos, Gothic Hardcore.  Definitely not for the squeamish.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Specialty product.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You're learning.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Where does he sell it?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Out of the back of bondage magazines mostly, but you can find it on the street if you look.  He'll also do commissions, for enough money...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Nothing illegal, it's always borderline.  Like if some freak wants to see a transvestite in a full rubber immersion suit getting an enema from a...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Alright, I get the picture.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: He cuts all kinds of other stuff into his movies; photographs, newsreel footage, subliminal images. Thinks he's making art.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Well, I'm in New York now.  What do you say to flying out and giving me a hand?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'm a working stiff, pops.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Take a vacation.  I'll pay you four hundred a day, plus expenses.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You want me to come out there and play private eye?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Consider it.  Meanwhile, dig up whatever Dino Velvet films you can. Get receipts.  I'll call back.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: See ya.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You didn't say it was gonna be this luxurious.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's their Presidential Suite.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Oh, come on, man, what are we doing in this flea bag?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's cheap, and people know to mind their own business. What have you got for me?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Wha... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Who is this, in the mask?  Who is he?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I told you, he's one of Dino Velvet's stock players...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Who is he, his name?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Nobody knows his name.  That's his thing.  He always wears a mask.  You never see his face.  He calls himself "Machine," that's what they call him.  Machine.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You don't need to be here.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What kind of Junior P.I. would I be if I didn't go with you?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I know if I had to pick, it'd be "Choke," or "Devil."

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: "Devil" frightened me as much as it excited me, but I'd be hard pressed to choose a favorite.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What's next?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm trying to figure that out myself.  I have to see Machine without his mask.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Still don't want to tell me what you're doing?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's money.  People use it to purchase goods and services.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Look... that's awful generous and everything...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's not my money.  The woman I got it from is never going to give it a second thought.  Let's not make a big deal out of this, okay?  Go be a race car driver.  Go run for President.  Whatever.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Mister Welles. You're very prompt.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I try to be.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Uh huh, pleasure.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Apparently Mr. Longdale has something he feels he simply must say before you and I speak.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Have a pleasant evening.  Will you have tea, Mister Welles?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: He's odd.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: He's a lawyer.  Please, sit, here...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: I've spoken to friends of mine and my husband's, in Harrisburg, in Lancaster and Hershey.  Asking about you.  I must say you have friends in influential places.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I've been privileged to provide services for people I admire.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: You are highly recommended.  Praised for your discretion... your strict adherence to confidentiality.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: As you know, my husband passed away recently.  Two weeks ago now.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: My condolences.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: His passing has left me with... something of a dilemma.  A terrible, terrible dilemma.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'll do whatever I can to help.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Pittsburgh?

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Mostly.  That's where he started his empire building.  He was a good man.  Notorious as an eccentric, but that was something he cultivated.  He wanted to be legendary.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: He succeeded.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: We were married forty-five years. Hard even for me to imagine.  We had our troubles.  There were plenty of places for him to be other than here, but he was always loyal to me, and I to him.  I loved him deeply.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Do you carry a gun, Mr. Welles?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I wear a gun when I can tell a client expects me to.  Other than that, there's never any reason.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Just curious.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: My husband was the only one with the combination to this safe.  I knew about it, but as far as I was concerned it was none of my business.  Not till now, that is.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You hired someone to open it.  I'll bet the lawyer loved that.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: There was nothing he could do.  My husband left everything to me.  I prevented anyone from seeing the contents.  I felt these were my husband's private things.  I didn't... I didn't realize...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Do you want to tell me what you found?

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Cash, stock certificates, and this...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: It's a film... of a girl being murdered.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm afraid I don't...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: This is a movie showing a girl being murdered.  She's sitting on a bed, and a man rapes her... and he begins to cut her with a knife...  I only watched what I could.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: I didn't know what to think.  I can't tell you how horrible it's been, to know this belonged to my husband.  To know that he watched this... this atrocity.  But, I can't go to the police...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Mrs. Christian... please, will you sit down a moment?  I want you to listen carefully. What you're talking about is a "snuff film."  But, from what I know, snuff films are a kind of... urban myth.  Like, red light district folklore.  There's no such thing, I can assure you.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Please, believe me.  This is probably a stag film.  Simulated rape.  Hard to stomach, and it might seem real, but there are ways of making it look realistic... fake blood and special effects...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: If you were to study it you'd see the camera cutting away... you'd see the tricks they can play...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: I'm telling you it's not that.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm sure it is.  It's probably something your husband was given as a bad joke.  More than likely he never even watched it.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Will you watch it and see for yourself?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Of course.  But, I'm certain it's nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You... you need to go to the police.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: I told you I can't, not yet.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You don't have any other choice.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: No.  For me to live with the ruin of my husband's name, I need know that whoever did this will be punished. If you can find them, I will take their names to the police.  I'll say my husband confessed on his death bed. I'll say I didn't have courage to come forward at first...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It won't work like that.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Any evidence you collect can be given to the police later, anonymously.  I've thought about it and there's no other way.  If you can't find them... if the only thing that comes from this film is that this is all my husband will be remembered for, well I can't let that happen.  I'm telling you I won't.  If there's no chance that poor girl's memory can be served, then I'll just have to spend my last days trying to forget her.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I deal in divorce cases.  Corporate investigations...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: You've found missing persons before.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Nothing remotely like this.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: I know what I'm asking.  Your compensation will be appropriate to the risk.  You'll need cash to buy information, and I'll provide it.  I feel responsible, Mr. Welles.  You saw what he did to her.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Okay...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: My husband never dealt with money personally, certainly not cash.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm not positive this means anything.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: The checks were for odd amounts...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: One was for two hundred thousand, one dollar and thirteen cents. Another was for three hundred thousand, six hundred fifty four dollars and seventy six cents...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Okay, I follow you so far...

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Totalled together, these five checks from five different accounts, they equal one million dollars.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You're joking.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: To the penny.  Exactly one million dollars in cash.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Hello... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm here.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Do you think the film could have cost that much?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: For a human life... murder on film, no statute of limitations.  Who knows?  It sure could have.  I'd like you to overnight me a copy of those checks, then put them in a safe deposit box.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Send it to me through the post office like we arranged.  No return address.  You dug this up all by yourself?

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: You told me to look, so I looked.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You're one hell of a detective, Mrs. Christian.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Mrs. Christian, Tom Welles here.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: How are you?  Having any luck?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I don't know if luck's the word. Are you feeling alright?

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: I've been ordered into bed.  The doctor says I've gotten the flu, or some other wretched ailment.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I hope it's nothing serious.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Nothing more than a bother.  Have you any news for me?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I've made progress.  I'm in Manhattan.  Once a few more pieces fall into place, I'll drive to you and give you an update.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: Fine...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I've got about five thousand left in cash, but I'll need another thirty, if you approve.

turns.speaker: MRS CHRISTIAN
turns.text: How will I get it to you?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: If you have a pencil and paper, I'll tell you how to send it.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Yes... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Hello, Mrs. Mathews, my name's Thomas Jones, I'm a state licensed investigator...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I've been hired as an independent contractor by the U.S. Resource Center for Missing Persons as part of an internal audit.  If you have any time over the next few days, I'd like to make an appointment to ask some questions about the disappearance of your daughter.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: I don't understand, who are... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm sorry, let me explain, the R.C.M.P. is a support organization and archive, not unlike the Center for Missing and Exploited Children in Washington.  I'm sure you've dealt with them before?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Yes, but...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: These volunteer organizations are sort of interconnected, functioning hand in hand with law enforcement. The R.C.M.P. brought me in to review their investigations...  ... fact-check their records, see if there's anything they missed, anything they should be doing different.  I'm here for a few days, before I head back up to Virginia. These reports go to the Justice Department eventually.  I spoke to your F.B.I. contact a few days ago, uh...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: What was the name... ? I've got it here somewhere...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Neil... Neil Cole.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Right, Agent Cole told me he'd call and let you know to expect me.  He didn't call?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Well, I'm following up on your daughter, Mary, height; five four, weight; hundred ten pounds, brown eyes, blonde hair.  Born April 24, 1976.  Missing June 11th, 1992.  A runaway, that's how she's listed. Is this information correct... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's very important you don't let this raise your expectations.  It's not going to effect any ongoing efforts.  All I'm saying is, please know, I'm not here to create any false hope.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: They hired you.  You're like, a private detective?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: That's exactly what I am.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: I didn't think there were private detectives anymore, except on TV.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You probably expect me to be wearing a trench coat and a hat.  Drinking whiskey, chasing women and getting beaten up by guys with broken noses. Want to know what it's really like? It's sitting in a car and staring at a hotel window for three days straight, pissing in a plastic bottle, pardon me, because some guy thinks his wife's cheating on him. Glamorous, huh?  And the guy who hired you, he has a hair-lip, dandruff and crooked teeth, and you could have told him the minute you laid eyes on him his wife's cheating, and you don't blame her.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: So, she didn't leave a note?  She never gave any indication where she might go, before she left?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: She just seemed... depressed... ?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: She didn't seem herself.  For months there never was any way to get her to talk about it.  One night we went to bed... the next morning she was gone.  She took some clothes.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: What was she running from?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: If there's anything you feel uncomfortable talking about, tell me, but I have to ask.  Your husband... he committed suicide?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: September 4th, 1993.  About a year after Mary disappeared.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: We were divorced by then.  Things fell apart... he was living with a friend...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Why do you think he did it?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: It got to be too much for him.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You have to forgive me, but in these circumstances... with your daughter...  Were there any indications of... any sort of abuse?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: There wasn't anything like that. The police and the FBI people asked, but there wasn't anything happened like that, never.  My husband... his heart broke when Mary left...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I didn't mean to...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: You try going through what we did. Bob couldn't take it, that's all. Christ, there's times when it still seems like I can't either.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I had to ask.  I apologize.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: No one knows what it's like.  You can't even imagine how much it hurts.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: People remember me from the news.  Can you drive me back now?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I... I shouldn't take anymore of your time.  Maybe we can finish tomorrow.  I'll call tomorrow...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Doesn't make much sense, does it? When everything's happy, when life's fine and you have every reason to believe there's a God, you don't bother.  Then, something horrible happens... that's when you start praying all the time.  That's when you start going to church.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: We're all like that.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Are you religious?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: You should be.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I've got what I need for my report. There is... there is one thing that bothers me though.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's not really my place, but it's not easy for me to set aside the private detective part of me either. See, I know a little about missing persons.  When kids run, they almost always leave a note.  It's guilt. They want to say goodbye.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: There wasn't one.  The police looked.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Do you think the police did a good job?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: I don't know.  I think so.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It is possible... and I know this isn't something you want to hear. Your daughter may have tried to hide a note where she thought you would eventually find it, but where she knew your husband would never find it.  She might have wanted to tell you something...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: No.  You don't have any reason to think that...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: If the police focused their search in her room, her belongings, well that'd be only natural, but they may have been looking in the wrong place.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: How... how can you say that to me...?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Will you let me look?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: My husband never laid a hand on her. She would have told me... she would have told me...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You're probably right, and I probably won't find anything. I don't have a right to ask this, and you can kick me out of your house if you want, but this is my profession and there's a part of me that can't let it go.  Police are just as human as you or I.  They could have missed something.  They probably didn't.  Wouldn't you rather know?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You were right.  I didn't find anything.  I'm going to run and get something to eat. Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: I think about it everyday.  But, every time the phone rings... every single time, I still think it's her.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It's been six years.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: What am I supposed to do?  Forget her?  Time heals all wounds, right?  She's all I think about, and I've learned to live with that.  But, you want the truth... the real truth? If I had a choice... if I had to choose, between her being out there, living a good life and being happy, and me not knowing; never finding out what happened to her...  ... or her being dead and me knowing...  I'd choose to know.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Hello... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Mrs. Mathews?  It's Thomas.  Do you remember, I was there a few weeks ago... asking about your daughter...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: I remember.  You just left...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I have to tell you something.  It won't be easy for you to hear.  It's about your daughter... Mary Anne...  When I... when I was there with you, her diary, in your attic, in silverware.  If you read it, you'll know what I'm telling you is true...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: What are you talking about... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: She went to California, to Los Angeles... she wanted to start over. She wanted to be an actress...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: What... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Mrs. Mathews, your daughter is dead. She's dead.

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Who is this... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Someone... some men, they took your daughter and they drugged her, and they took her to a motel room... they did terrible things to her...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: They brought her into the room... one man, he put a knife to her throat and he raped her...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: He raped her and...and...and he murdered her...he cut her up with knifes...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: No... no... no...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: They killed her, and they took her out in the forest somewhere and they buried her...

turns.speaker: MRS MATHEWS
turns.text: Why... why are you doing this to me... ?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: They murdered her, Mrs. Mathews, I'm sorry.  It happened a month after she ran away.  She's been dead all this time...

turns.speaker: NUN
turns.text: Yes... I remember Mary

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You... you do?  You're sure? Please, Sister, will you take another look, make sure...

turns.speaker: NUN
turns.text: Yes.  I remember her.

turns.speaker: NUN
turns.text: Do you know what happened to her?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'm trying to find out.  She was a runaway.  I'm looking into it for her parents.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: What is this?

turns.speaker: NUN
turns.text: Those are her belongings.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Her belongings?

turns.speaker: NUN
turns.text: That's her suitcase.  I had forgotten it, till you showed me her picture.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Whatever possessed you to keep this all this time?

turns.speaker: NUN
turns.text: She was the kindest, sweetest girl you'd ever want to meet.  Oh, I adored her.  I supposed I always hoped she'd be back.  After a time, all I could do was pray she had moved on to better things.  Can you get this suitcase to her parents, if you think it's appropriate?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'll do what I can.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Your son-in-law dealt with the dry cleaning franchise during the day, saw that woman every night.  The specifics are in the report, and information about the woman.  It's unpleasant, I know.  I apologize...

turns.speaker: POLITICIAN
turns.text: None too discreet, is he?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: No, sir, he is not.

turns.speaker: POLITICIAN
turns.text: He's an imbecile.  I tried to warn my daughter, but what can you do?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: The um... you'll find my invoice in the envelope. If that's all...

turns.speaker: POLITICIAN
turns.text: Yes, Mister Welles, thank you.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Certainly, Senator.  If I can ever be of further assistance.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Okay, I'll take it all.

turns.speaker: SALESPERSON
turns.text: Excellent.  we accept MasterCard and American Express.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Cash.

turns.speaker: SALESPERSON
turns.text: Alright.  May I have your phone number, area code first?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: No, you may not.

turns.speaker: SALESPERSON
turns.text: Okay.  Fine.

turns.speaker: SALESPERSON
turns.text: I'm required by state law to inform you that, while it's perfectly legal for you to purchase these items, it is illegal for you to use them for any sort of...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Yeah, I know the spiel.  If you could bag it, I'll be on my way, thank you.

turns.speaker: SALESPERSON
turns.text: Certainly, sir.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Don't you think it kind of defeats the purpose?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: The mirror.  You can't see yourself in it.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I don't want to.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yeah.  She'd be half as strict as you.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: But she wouldn't let Dad treat me like that.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Look, you gotta stand up for yourself. Learn to fight back.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Rick...I can't.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Never say can't.  Just do what I do.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Alice, you think you can leave?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Kincaid and Joey died last night.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: You alright?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Kristen...

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I heard you screaming.  Was it a bad one?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: It was bad.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Doesn't the dream master work for you anymore?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I can't find him.
